key_points: Tiger Woods is making a return to competitive golf at the PNC Championship with his son Charlie, months after a severe car crash.
Woods suffered significant orthopedic injuries to his right leg, including fractures to his tibia and fibula bones, in the February 23 car crash.
A source described Wood's recovery from the accident as 'incredible', highlighting his focus on physical therapy despite the pain.
Woods' children, Charlie and Sam, have been a 'huge motivation' for him throughout his recovery.
According to a source, Woods is 'very pleased' to play with his son Charlie and attributes his recovery to a 'positive attitude and dedication'.
Despite his remarkable recovery, Woods admitted he won't be able to compete at the PGA Tour level for some time.
Woods expressed his intention to play rounds of golf 'here or there' in a more casual context despite his limitations.
Rather than dwelling on his accident, Woods is looking forward to the future.
In a statement, Woods said this year has been tough with 'tough memories' but also had 'great times' and looks forward to turning the page.
The story emphasizes Tiger Woods' determination and positive outlook throughout his recovery process.
